Today, the House is voting on H.R. 8294, which combines bills from the T-HUD, Agriculture, Energy & Water, Financial Services, Interior, and Military Construction/VA subcommittees.

This is informally called a "minibus" as opposed to an omnibus, which would combine all 12 bills.

Before the bills are considered on the floor, they must go through the @RulesDemocrats Committee to determine the structure of debate & amendments.

These amendments can be submitted by any Member of Congress.

Through these subcommittees, Members work on behalf of the American people to fund critical priorities in areas such as education, healthcare, food access, & housing.

Once the bills are approved by the subcommittees, they must pass the full committee before going to the floor.

6/ This bill isn't a comprehensive attempt to reform our elections. This bill just aims to make sure that presidential elections can't be stolen through a manipulation of the electoral college process.

We have much more to do to secure elections and make sure everyone can vote.
5/ Finally, this bill makes clear the Vice President's role is just ceremonial. Trump's hail mary play - the VP blocking certification - is no longer even a remote possibility.

4/ The bill also removes an ambiguous provision in the 1887 law that Trump argued allows state legislatures to appoint their own electors if they judged there to be fraud in the election. Now, states won't be able to change the rules of how electors are chosen after the election.

3/ Next, this bill makes it harder for members of Congress to object to the certified results submitted by a state. Right now, it only takes one Senator or one House member with a conspiracy theory to force a vote. The new threshold is 20% of House/Senate members.

2/ First, this bill would make sure that every state correctly certifies election results. How? By creating an expedited new court process to stop fraud if a state government attempts to ignore the will of the voters by sending more than one set of results, or none at all.
